text: we talk a lot about the narcissism of
the internet but there's an entire genre
of Internet content that rejects all
that it focuses on a different body part
well two on Facebook and YouTube we
watch disembodied hands cook party foods
make DIY slime and execute creative
household tax and hands are taking over
more and more online content a quarter
of video views on the Facebook pages of
big media companies are now hands only
no faces no bodies just hands
[Music]
there's a specific grammar to the
hands-only video it's important that the
hands come from the bottom of the frame
instead of the top a hand reaching down
from above
feels like a creepy disembodied hand
when that comes from the bottom feels
like your own it used to be that
instructional TV shows were built around
celebrity hosts filmed on sets with wide
camera shots these shows could make
viewers feel like they were hanging out
with Rachael Ray or Martha Stewart
but they didn't mimic the sensation of
actually doing it yourself social media
shows don't need hosts on the Internet
we're the ones sharing recipes and
dispensing life hacks we provide the
commentary and our Facebook friends
supply the human connection the
Internet's hands feel like our own
except more skillful accomplished and
efficient and as millions of BuzzFeed
video views suggest that feeling is
really appealing call me a nut but is it
wrong that I can't take my eyes off the
guy's hand I want to know what the rest
of this man looks like and if you think
why are we so drawn to this feeling of
vicarious competence why is it so
appealing relaxing even hands-only
videos provide relief from a place that
often seems more governed by how we look
than what we can do the Internet's focus
on faces put so much pressure on
building brands and amassing followings
around personalities but hands videos
are soothing in their anonymity when we
watch them we get to think about making
things in the world instead of endlessly
refining our faces bodies and personas
even when hands aren't so blank their
glamour feels democratic take the
explosion of nail art nail art
eliminates all the distractions of the
face and body focusing instead on
artistry and immaculate detail the
beauty here doesn't rely on the nose you
were born with or the nose that you
bought it's a pure creative achievement
people seem to be clear either detailing
if the face has come to represent
narcissism online the hand projects a
quiet seriousness of purpose its
opposable thumb allows it to wield tools
plush symbols and now type out texts and
it's probably not a coincidence that the
hands image has risen online just as
mobile devices have taken over our lives
it's easy to focus on the dark side of
the internet how it's ruining a
generation of kids whose faces will
never be free of its surveillance hands
represent a more hopeful part of the
Internet the part that helps you learn
stuff that democratizes knowledge and
that encourages action and innovation in
an online landscape of endless chatter
the hand is all business
hey this is Amanda this is Shane he
edits the videos she writes the videos
you watch the videos and if you like
this video like comment and subscribe
and tell us what body part should be
fetishize next let us know in the
comments we are very thirsty
[Music]
